content.webTitle: Claudio Ranieri turns Thinkerman for Leicester win against Norwich

fields.headline: Claudio Ranieri turns Thinkerman for Leicester win against Norwich
fields.bodyText: Going for the jugular once ended up costing Claudio Ranieri the chance to win the Champions League with Chelsea but these days he rarely gets a tactical decision wrong and so it proved against Norwich when the Tinkerman-turned-Thinkerman put all his chips on blue and walked away with three points. With the game goalless, only 11 minutes remaining and Leicester running out of ideas as to how to break down a resilient and disciplined Norwich, Ranieri took the view it was time to twist not stick and replaced Daniel Amartey, a right-back, with Leonardo Ulloa, a centre-forward. Marc Albrighton, whose crossing had been so disappointing in the previous 89 minutes, finally delivered the low, inviting centre Ranieri had been demanding. “When he received the ball I was saying: ‘Cross on the floor, cross on the floor,’ because they are very good in the air” and Ulloa, following the faintest of touches from Jamie Vardy, was in the right place at the right time to convert. For Ranieri, who had already introduced Jeffrey Schlupp wide on the left for his first appearance in three months, switched Albrighton to the right and moved Riyad Mahrez in behind Vardy to try to give Leicester some more attacking thrust, it was a case of fortune favours the brave and provided an insight into the manager’s mindset with 11 games remaining. “I took a lot of risks,” he said. “I said: ‘In or out – it’s not important now. One point is nothing – we have to win today.’ You can lose but it’s only one point less than a draw. We took the risk but the manager is hired for this reason. I enjoy when there is something to do from my side of things. Saturday was good because when you make a change and the change turns out to find the solution, it’s fantastic.” Norwich deserved at least a point from a game in which Leicester struggled to cope with opponents who employed a three-man central defence and sat deep. Ranieri’s side found themselves in the unusual position of having plenty of the ball – this was only the third occasion this season when they have had the most possession in a game – and looked confused what to do with it at times; there were 58 minutes on the clock when Vardy had their first shot on target. It is a situation Leicester may have to get used to over the remainder of the season, starting with West Brom’s visit on Tuesday. “I expect more games like this, teams coming here with five defenders,” said Ranieri, who is likely to be without N’Golo Kanté after the midfielder picked up a slight hamstring injury. “There isn’t any easy matches. Every match is a battle but I rate this kind of performance because Norwich are fighting to avoid relegation and if you score at the end of the match it proves the fitness and the stamina is OK. Also the concentration and also the belief was there.” Norwich have taken only one point from a possible 21 and the visit of an in-form Chelsea side on Tuesday will not exactly fill their supporters with optimism. Yet this was a decent performance that could have yielded so much more if Cameron Jerome had not wasted a golden headed opportunity in the first half.“I think if we’d have come in at 0-0 we’d have been fairly satisfied, probably a bit disappointed not to score a goal, but after that sucker-punch we come in feeling even worse,” said Russell Martin. “It is what it is. We have to take the positives, it’s as simple as that. We still believe we’re a good enough side to be in this league next season and we’re still out of the bottom three.” Man of the match Jonny Howson (Norwich City)
